ADAMS DEBATE
TRYOUTS TODAY
Junior tryouts for the Herbert B. Adams Debate, to take
place before the assembly
some time in February, will be
held today in Room 112, Gilman Hall. Tomorrow afternoon at the same time the senior team will be selected.
The subject of the debate,
on which the candidates will
be expected to have prepared
three-minute speeches, is: Resolved, That the United States
shall not employ armed force
in Latin America, except in
time of war.

Dear Sirs:
I am a prodigal son.
I began pipe-smoking with Edgeworth. But after a while I began to
wander, trying other tobaccos, experimenting to see if there were any better
tobacco for the pipe.
I have tried most of the best knoWn
brands and a number of the more obscure, both imported and domestic,
but they didn't suit.
So now I have returned—I am using
Edgeworth again, satisfied that no
better tobacco is made.
"And the prodigal son partook of
the fatted calf"; I bought a new pipe
when I returned to Edgeworth.
With many thanks for my cool, mel'
low,sweet smokes,I am,

Very truly yours,
D."

LIBERAL EDUCATION ON TRIAL
The experiment of the "reading period," now being carried on
• at Harvard, is probably the most interesting attempt to give a
solid foundation to the term "liberal, education" that has been
• ::tried in many years. For two weeks preceding examinations.
formai instruction has been suspended at Harvard, and in its
place, the students are supposed to do a certain amount of required reading, carefully planned in advance by the instructors.
• This scheme is, in reality, one of the best tests to which the
• so-called liberal education can be put. One of the greatest advantages claimed for the modern collegiate education is that it should
create in the mind of the student a certain amount of genuine
curiosity and interest in cultural matters which would probably
lie dormant were it not for the stimulus which the years spent
• at college create. In other words, the real test of the college
education is the effect on the Bachelor of Arts after he has left
the environment of his college. If he has developed a taste for
good literature, for example, which becomes an ineradicable part
of. his make-up, his education might be termed a success.
Therefore, to a smaller degree, of course, the efficacy of the
"reading period" is an index of the liberalizing effect of the liberal education. If students, left entirely on their own for three
weeks, will honestly go about the business of educating themselves, there is a justification for the collegiate education. If not,
the liberal education is just as much an anomoly as so many of
• its. critics say it is.

A WORD ABOUT SUPPORT
• Basketball, Hopkins' newly inaugurated sport, gets its first trial
tonight, and according to the opinion of many of those who are
in the inner circle of Hopkins athletics, its failure or success will
mark the failure or success of all minor sports. If the student
body shows, by the interest it evinces in the team, that it thinks
basketball a worth-while sport, the Athletic Council will probably
aceept this manifestation of interest as an indication that the
student body approves and wants minor sports; if not, the Council may be led to believe that minor sports are not worth to the
student body as a whole the money spent on them.
Of course, in gauging the actual success of the team in winning games, it is necessary to keep in mind several facts. First
of all, the team is late in getting started. In the second place,
the members are playing together for the first time. It is, therefore, hardly reasonable to expect victories in the majority of the
games. The student body must take cognizance of these facts
in judging the team's excellence, and should not let its greenness
be a detriment to the amount of support it receives.

OUNTAINS blocked the trail of
the pioneers who opened up the
far west. But that impelling urge of the
true pioneer — to explore and know the
country beyond — spurred them to surmount these barriers.
In office and laboratory, mountainous
problems in management, in methods and
in scientific research confront the men of
the Bell Telephone System. Yet that same
IV

pioneering instinct—the urge to better the
known and attain the unknown — will
carry them through.
Just as it has brought them through the
difficulties in achieving nation-wide uniform service, efficiently engineered and
wisely administered. To the modern
frontiersmen who carry on this work to
still greater developments will be given the
thrill of adventure that lies in discovery.

Poorly Attended
Little business of importance was
transacted at the Junior Class meeting on last Thursday. A poor attendance and the nearness of examinations caused postponement of discussion of the Junior banquet and
plans for the annual Junior Frolic.
This party has been known in the
past years under various names such
as "Bowery Ball," "Kiddies Frolic,"
and last year was the "Night on the
Spanish Main." The date for the
Junior banquet has not yet been set,
but is being waited expectantly by
the members of the two lower
classes, to whom it means a beginning of real hostilities.

Enoch Light Now
Playing in Berlin

11111 to11

Enoch Light, who graduated from
Hopkins two years ago, is now playing with his orchestra in Berlin.
According to Roger Conant, a former member of Light's band, the
Hopkins violinist's orchestra is the
most popular jazz troupe now playing at the German capital.
The year following his graduation
Light made a tour of the southern
and western sections of the United
States, playing for two weeks at the
Century Theater as a stage attraction.
Considerable comment was caused
at the time, due .to the fact that
Light advertised the orchestra as
the Blue Jays and represented it as
a Hopkins organization, whereas
many of the members had no connection with this University.

Junior tryouts for the Herbert B. Adams Debate, to take

some time in February, will be
held today in Room 112, Gilman Hall. Tomorrow afternoon at the same time the senior team will be selected.

be expected to have prepared
three-minute speeches, is: Resolved, That the United States
shall not employ armed force
in Latin America, except in
time of war.

LIBERAL EDUCATION ON TRIAL
The experiment of the "reading period," now being carried on
• at Harvard, is probably the most interesting attempt to give a
solid foundation to the term "liberal, education" that has been
• ::tried in many years. For two weeks preceding examinations.
formai instruction has been suspended at Harvard, and in its
place, the students are supposed to do a certain amount of required reading, carefully planned in advance by the instructors.
• This scheme is, in reality, one of the best tests to which the
• so-called liberal education can be put. One of the greatest advantages claimed for the modern collegiate education is that it should
create in the mind of the student a certain amount of genuine
curiosity and interest in cultural matters which would probably
lie dormant were it not for the stimulus which the years spent
• at college create. In other words, the real test of the college
education is the effect on the Bachelor of Arts after he has left
the environment of his college. If he has developed a taste for
good literature, for example, which becomes an ineradicable part
of. his make-up, his education might be termed a success.
Therefore, to a smaller degree, of course, the efficacy of the
"reading period" is an index of the liberalizing effect of the liberal education. If students, left entirely on their own for three
weeks, will honestly go about the business of educating themselves, there is a justification for the collegiate education. If not,
the liberal education is just as much an anomoly as so many of
• its. critics say it is.

A WORD ABOUT SUPPORT
• Basketball, Hopkins' newly inaugurated sport, gets its first trial
tonight, and according to the opinion of many of those who are
in the inner circle of Hopkins athletics, its failure or success will
mark the failure or success of all minor sports. If the student
body shows, by the interest it evinces in the team, that it thinks
basketball a worth-while sport, the Athletic Council will probably
aceept this manifestation of interest as an indication that the
student body approves and wants minor sports; if not, the Council may be led to believe that minor sports are not worth to the
student body as a whole the money spent on them.
Of course, in gauging the actual success of the team in winning games, it is necessary to keep in mind several facts. First
of all, the team is late in getting started. In the second place,
the members are playing together for the first time. It is, therefore, hardly reasonable to expect victories in the majority of the
games. The student body must take cognizance of these facts
in judging the team's excellence, and should not let its greenness
be a detriment to the amount of support it receives.

Poorly Attended
Little business of importance was
transacted at the Junior Class meeting on last Thursday. A poor attendance and the nearness of examinations caused postponement of discussion of the Junior banquet and
plans for the annual Junior Frolic.
This party has been known in the
past years under various names such
as "Bowery Ball," "Kiddies Frolic,"
and last year was the "Night on the
Spanish Main." The date for the
Junior banquet has not yet been set,
but is being waited expectantly by
the members of the two lower
classes, to whom it means a beginning of real hostilities.

Enoch Light Now
Playing in Berlin

11111 to11

Enoch Light, who graduated from
Hopkins two years ago, is now playing with his orchestra in Berlin.
According to Roger Conant, a former member of Light's band, the
Hopkins violinist's orchestra is the
most popular jazz troupe now playing at the German capital.
The year following his graduation
Light made a tour of the southern
and western sections of the United
States, playing for two weeks at the
Century Theater as a stage attraction.
Considerable comment was caused
at the time, due .to the fact that
Light advertised the orchestra as
the Blue Jays and represented it as
a Hopkins organization, whereas
many of the members had no connection with this University.
